Aquatic Resources Screening with Fieldwo.RC1: The United States Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) regulates jurisdictional waters of the United States (WOTUS) under the federal Clean Water Act (CWA), via CWA Section 404 and Section 401 permits. The Nevada Department of Environmental Protection (NDEP) regulates and permits various activities in aquatic resources determined to be Waters of the State (WOTS).
Aquatic Resources Screening with Fieldwo.Des1: An Aquatic Resources Screening Report is a technical memo that describes the lateral extent of aquatic features located within a project boundary and assesses the need for the proposed project to obtain permits from the USACE and NDEP.
Aquatic Resources Screening with Fieldwo.Methods1: UES will conduct a desktop review of publicly available data sources and aerial imagery. UES will also conduct a site visit to document current field conditions of the project area identified by the Client. Field data to be collected includes georeferenced photographs, ordinary high water mark (OHWM) measurements, and general site descriptions.
Aquatic Resources Screening with Fieldwo.CPI1:
• Project boundary in electronic format (.kml or .shp)
  • Project description
  • Written notice to proceed
Aquatic Resources Screening with Fieldwo.AnL1:
• All project area is accessible.
  • Weather is conducive to field work.
  • Client comments will be editorial in nature.
Aquatic Resources Screening with Fieldwo.Del1:
• A draft screening report will be submitted for the client to review.
  • One round of client comments will be incorporated into the draft report.
  • A final report will be submitted to the client for their records.

The Nevada Department of Environmental Protection (NDEP) regulates and permits various activities in aquatic resources determined to be Waters of the State (WOTS).
Aquatic Resources Desktop Screening.Des1: A Desktop Aquatic Resources Screening Report is a technical memo that describes the extent of expected aquatic features located within a project boundary and assesses the need for the proposed project to obtain a permit from the USACE and NDEP, to the extent practicable without a field visit.
Aquatic Resources Desktop Screening.Methods1: UES will conduct a desktop review of publicly available data sources and aerial imagery.
Aquatic Resources Desktop Screening.CPI1:
• Project Boundary in digital format (.shp or .kmz)
  • A project description will be provided.
Aquatic Resources Desktop Screening.AnL1: • This scope does not include the preparation of any permit applications, or take the place of formal consultation with USACE or NDEP.
Aquatic Resources Desktop Screening.Del1:
• Results of the review of publicly available sources, including assessments of the jurisdictional limits for each federal and state agency. This includes relevant project mapping.
  • A list of recommended and potential permits from the USACE and NDEP that may be relevant to the project.
  • The Client will receive a draft of the report and UES will address one round of comments/revisions as requested by the Client. The report will then be finalized and provided electronically to the Client for their files and inclusion in the project files.

NDEP Individual Working in Waters.RC1: During the planned project activities, work will be done in watercourses, drainages, stormwater channels, and/or other features that are Waters of the State of Nevada (WOTS). WOTS are regulated by the Nevada Division of Environmental Protection (NDEP). NDEP requires a Working in Waters permit for any work done with 'heavy equipment' in WOTS. An individual Working in Waters (WIW) Permit is valid for up to five (5) years from issuance.
NDEP Individual Working in Waters.Des1: UES will coordinate on behalf of the client to obtain an individual WIW permit from NDEP. This task includes field work, client coordination, submittal package, and agency coordination.
NDEP Individual Working in Waters.Methods1: UES shall generate a submission package for an individual working in waters permit, including relevant mapping and 'before' photos. After a draft submission to the client for approval (if requested), UES will submit the package to the NDEP for the purpose of obtaining an Individual Working in Waters Permit. Coordination with the NDEP, if necessary, is included in the submittal package.
NDEP Individual Working in Waters.CPI1:
• Project boundary in electronic format (.kml or .shp)
  • Project description and Best Management Practices (BMP) plan
  • A completed Client Data Sheet upon request by UES
  • A signed and returned Notice of Intent upon request by UES
NDEP Individual Working in Waters.AnL1: • NDEP response and processing time is subject to variance

NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit.Task1: NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit
NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit.AcTask1: NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit
NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit.RC1: During the planned project activities, work will be done in watercourses, drainages, stormwater channels, and/or other features that are Waters of the State of Nevada (WOTS). WOTS are regulated by the Nevada Division of Environmental Protection (NDEP). NDEP requires a Working in Waters permit for any work done with “heavy equipment” in WOTS. A temporary Working in Waters (WIW) Permit is valid for 180 days from issuance. A project may obtain up to two temporary permits per project (which may be defined differently by NDEP than the client) before an individual permit (valid for up to five years) is necessary.
NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit.Des1: UES will coordinate on behalf of the client to obtain a temporary WIW permit from NDEP. This task includes field work, client coordination, submittal package, monitoring log, and agency coordination.
NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit.Methods1: UES shall generate a submission package for a temporary working in waters permit, including relevant mapping and “before” photos. After a draft submission to the client for approval (if requested), UES will submit the package to the Nevada Department of Environmental Protection (NDEP) for the purpose of obtaining a Temporary Working in Waters Permit. Coordination with the NDEP, if necessary, is included in the submittal package. UES will also generate a project-specific Daily Monitoring Log for the Clients use or reference. The Notice of Intent application fee will be paid by UES to expedite processing. This fee is $350, plus a processing fee.
NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit.CPI1:
• Project boundary in electronic format (.kml or .shp)
  • Project description and Best Management Practices (BMP) plan
  • A completed Client Data Sheet upon request by UES
  • A signed and returned Notice of Intent upon request by UES
NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit.AnL1: • NDEP response and processing time is subject to variance

Phase I ESA.RC1: The purpose of a Phase I ESA is to determine the presence of Recognized Environmental Conditions (RECs) that may be present at the subject property due to past or present uses and/or RECs that may exist at other properties in the vicinity which could adversely affect conditions on the subject property. This report is intended to permit the user to satisfy one of the requirements to qualify for the innocent landowner, contiguous property owner, or bona fide prospective purchaser limitations on Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation Liability Act (CERCLA) liability. This report will also satisfy the requirement for conducting All Appropriate Inquiry (AAI) into the prior ownership and use of the subject property consistent with good commercial or customary practice, as well as to qualify for protections against liability under the innocent landowner, bona fide prospective purchaser, and contiguous property owner defense.
Phase I ESA.Des1: This assessment will consist of the following: Conduct an on-site reconnaissance of the property, including a cursory review of adjacent properties. This will involve pertinent interviews with owners/occupants, property managers, or neighboring businesses to determine historical uses of the property and nearby properties. Additionally, a review of various Local, State, Federal, and Tribal databases will be conducted to help identify RECs in connection with the subject property and nearby properties. The search will include all databases required by ASTM E1527-21, covering minimal required search distances from the center of the subject property and several supplemental databases. Finally, a comprehensive report will be prepared, detailing the assessment findings and including supporting documentation.
Phase I ESA.Methods1: Conduct an on-site reconnaissance of the property, including a cursory review of adjacent properties. This will involve pertinent interviews with owners/occupants, property managers, or neighboring businesses to determine historical uses of the property and nearby properties. Additionally, a review of various Local, State, Federal, and Tribal databases will be conducted to help identify RECs in connection with the subject property and nearby properties. The search will include all databases required by ASTM E1527-21, covering minimal required search distances from the center of the subject property and several supplemental databases. Finally, prepare a comprehensive report detailing the assessment findings and including supporting documentation.
Phase I ESA.AnL1:
• Client will provide the right of entry to conduct the assessment.
  • No known sources or possible sources of contamination will be obstructed or obscured by materials or equipment.
  • If there are any restrictions or special requirements regarding the site, these will be made known to UES by the Client prior to commencing the assessment work.
  • Interviewees will not withhold information from or intentionally mislead the interviewer.
Phase I ESA.Del1:
• A draft screening report will be submitted for the client to review.
  • One round of client comments will be incorporated into the draft report.
  • A final report will be submitted to the client for their records.

This report is intended to permit the user to satisfy one of the requirements to qualify for the innocent landowner, contiguous property owner, or bona fide prospective purchaser limitations on Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation Liability Act (CERCLA) liability. This report will also satisfy the requirement for conducting All Appropriate Inquiry (AAI) into the prior ownership and use of the subject property consistent with good commercial or customary practice, as well as to qualify for protections against liability under the innocent landowner, bona fide prospective purchaser, and contiguous property owner defense.

Biological Assessment.RC1: A Biological Assessment is a technical report that describes the potential to impact Federally protected species within a project boundary and is often required under the Endangered Species Act (ESA) in the United States when federal agencies undertake or approve projects that might affect protected species or their critical habitats. This report is utilized by the US Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) to initiate formal consultation to analyze impacts to protected species and develop mitigation to minimize impacts to an acceptable level.
Biological Assessment.Des1: UES will prepare a Biological Assessment that documents the baseline of the subject property that includes a literature review and the results of field investigations including vegetation types, and narrative habitat discussions. The BA will analyze potential impacts and recommend protections measures.
Biological Assessment.Methods1: UES will perform field investigations to analyze and assess site conditions for categories of potential impacts, unless the Client provides data for previous investigations. The Client will receive a draft of the report and UES will address one round of comments/revisions as requested by the Client, one round of comments/revisions as requested by BOR, and one round of comments/revisions as requested by USFWS. The report will then be finalized and provided electronically to USFWS and/or other agencies concurrently for preparation of the final Biological Opinion. This task also anticipates and includes time for agency and client meetings and coordination.
Biological Assessment.CPI1:
• A full project description of the proposed work including a description of all work proposed to occur within federally managed lands.
  • All available georeferenced shapefiles and/or Google Earth KMZ/KML files for the proposed project.
Biological Assessment.Del1:
• Draft Biological Assessment Report
  • One round of client comments will be addressed

Environmental Assessment.RC1: This attachment describes the scope and schedule for preparation of an Environmental Assessment (EA) and facilitation of the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) process. NEPA is a procedural statute intended to ensure Federal agencies consider the environmental impacts of their actions in their decision-making process. Compliance is required under 40 CFR 1500 when there is federal funding, other federal permits required, federal approvals, and rights-of-ways grants.
Environmental Assessment.Des1: This Work Plan includes the tasks, schedule, and budget for the preparation of the EA and support services completing the federally required resource investigations, submitting the application and reports that allows them issuance of federal approval required for the expansion.

USACE Permitting.RC1: Section 404 of the Clean Water Act requires a permit from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) for the discharge of dredged or fill material into waters of the United States, including wetlands. Section 10 of the Rivers and Harbors Act requires a USACE permit for work or structures in, over or under navigable waters. The Carson River is a navigable water, so both Section 404 and Section 10 permitting is required.
USACE Permitting.Des1: UES will prepare and submit a Complete Application package to the USACE to obtain the necessary Section 404 and Section 10 permit coverage for the project. UES will also coordinate with the Nevada Division of Environmental Protection (NDEP) to obtain the associated Section 401 Water Quality Certification.
USACE Permitting.Methods1: UES will compile a Complete Application package meeting USACE requirements, including the Section 404 permit application form, aquatic resources delineation report, biological resources report, cultural resources report, and project plans. The project plans will show the limits of USACE jurisdictional waters overlain with the proposed design to calculate impact quantities. UES will coordinate with the project engineer to ensure the project description, design, and avoidance and minimization measures are accurately represented.
USACE Permitting.CPI1:
• Project Boundary in digital format (.shp or .kmz)
  • Site and constructions plans
USACE Permitting.AnL1:
• The project can be authorized under USACE Nationwide Permits.
  • Client revisions to the applications materials will be minor.
  • Any required compensatory mitigation plan, alternatives analysis, or additional agency coordination is not included. Application fees are to be paid by the client directly to the agencies.
USACE Permitting.Dependency1: Completion of aquatic resources delineation, biological resources survey, and cultural resources assessment; receipt of project plans showing jurisdictional impacts.

NEPA DNA.RC1: The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) must comply with the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) before issuing a right-of-way grant for the project. NEPA analysis is required when a federal action may impact the human or natural environment. The NEPA analysis will take the form of a Determination of NEPA Adequacy (DNA) that tiers off two existing BLM Environmental Assessments (EAs).
NEPA DNA.Des1: UES will prepare a DNA document that analyzes the environmental impacts of the project and demonstrates that the existing NEPA analysis in the Las Vegas In-Valley Area EA is adequate to cover the proposed action. The DNA will describe the project, assess impacts to key resources, and identify any additional mitigation measures needed.
NEPA DNA.Methods1: UES will compile a baseline inventory of environmental conditions for key resources and assess potential impacts to each resource as well as mitigation measures. UES will prepare a draft DNA with resource specialist input for BLM and project owner review.
NEPA DNA.AnL1:
• BLM comments will be editorial; no new analysis or field work needed.
  • A 30-day comment period will occur but no public meetings are required.
  • BLM will issue a Finding of No Significant Impact/Decision Record.
  • Only the proposed action and no-action alternative will be analyzed. Preparing an Environmental Impact Statement is not included. Attendance at any public meetings is not included. Any new surveys, studies or design changes requiring additional analysis are not included.
NEPA DNA.Del1:
• Draft DNA for client and BLM review, final DNA based on comments, and support for the 30-day public comment period, if required.
  • Coordination with BLM in preparing a Finding of No Significant Impact and Decision Record.
NEPA DNA.Dependency1: Notice to proceed and receipt of relevant project data.

Agency Coordination.RC1: Projects requiring permits from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) often involve coordination with various other federal, state, and local regulatory agencies. Effective agency coordination is key to keeping the permitting process on track and avoiding delays.
Agency Coordination.Des1: UES will provide up to 12 hours of professional time to coordinate with the USACE, Nevada Division of Environmental Protection (NDEP), and other agencies as required to facilitate the Section 404/10 and 401 permitting processes.
Agency Coordination.Methods1: UES will maintain proactive communication with the regulatory agencies throughout the permitting process. UES will work to establish a positive rapport with agency staff, provide timely responses to information requests, and keep the agencies informed of project status and developments. Specific coordination activities may include phone calls, emails, virtual meetings, transmittal of requested information, and internal strategy sessions to plan responses to agency comments or requests. UES will keep the client informed of agency interactions and work collaboratively to resolve any regulatory issues or concerns that may arise.
Agency Coordination.AnL1:
• Agency coordination will not exceed 12 professional hours.
  • Coordination will be with USACE, NDEP and other state or federal agencies as applicable.
  • UES will have timely access to any project information needed to respond to agency requests.
  • Any required permit revisions will be minor in nature.
  • The 12-hour budget is an estimate based on a typical permitting process. If additional agency coordination is required beyond this budget, or if substantial permit revisions are needed, a contract amendment would be required. Any required permit application fees are not included.
Agency Coordination.Del1: • Ongoing agency coordination through the duration of the permitting process, up to the approved budget amount
Agency Coordination.RC2: Projects requiring permits from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) often involve coordination with various other federal, state, and local regulatory agencies. Effective agency coordination is key to keeping the permitting process on track and avoiding delays.

Specific coordination activities may include phone calls, emails, virtual meetings, transmittal of requested information, and internal strategy sessions to plan responses to agency comments or requests. UES will keep the client informed of agency interactions and work collaboratively to resolve any regulatory issues or concerns that may arise.
Agency Coordination.AnL2:
• Agency coordination will not exceed 12 professional hours.
  • Coordination will be with USACE, NDEP and other state or federal agencies as applicable.
  • UES will have timely access to any project information needed to respond to agency requests.
  • Any required permit revisions will be minor in nature.
  • The 12-hour budget is an estimate based on a typical permitting process. If additional agency coordination is required beyond this budget, or if substantial permit revisions are needed, a contract amendment would be required. Any required permit application fees are not included.
Agency Coordination.Del2: • Ongoing agency coordination through the duration of the permitting process, up to the approved budget amount
Agency Coordination.RC3: Projects requiring permits from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) often involve coordination with various other federal, state, and local regulatory agencies. Effective agency coordination is key to keeping the permitting process on track and avoiding delays.
Agency Coordination.Des3: UES will provide up to 12 hours of professional time to coordinate with the USACE, Nevada Division of Environmental Protection (NDEP), and other agencies as required to facilitate the Section 404/10 and 401 permitting processes.
Agency Coordination.Methods3: UES will maintain proactive communication with the regulatory agencies throughout the permitting process. UES will work to establish a positive rapport with agency staff, provide timely responses to information requests, and keep the agencies informed of project status and developments. Specific coordination activities may include phone calls, emails, virtual meetings, transmittal of requested information, and internal strategy sessions to plan responses to agency comments or requests. UES will keep the client informed of agency interactions and work collaboratively to resolve any regulatory issues or concerns that may arise.

Aquatic Resources Jurisdictional Delinea.RC1: An Aquatic Resources Delineation is required to support any permit application submitted to the USACE. The delineation identifies the presence and extent of potential waters of the U.S. within the project area, including wetlands, streams, and other water features. The USACE Sacramento District has established minimum standards for delineations.
Aquatic Resources Jurisdictional Delinea.Des1: UES will conduct field surveys to delineate any aquatic resources within the project area.
Aquatic Resources Jurisdictional Delinea.Methods1: Streams will be delineated using USACE guidance on identifying the OHWM. Wetlands will be delineated following the 1987 Corps of Engineers Wetlands Delineation Manual and applicable regional supplement. UES will collect field data on all delineated features. The survey results will be used to prepare the Aquatic Resources Delineation report. Delineated features will be mapped and total acreages and linear feet calculated. The report will meet USACE Sacramento District minimum standards.
Aquatic Resources Jurisdictional Delinea.CPI1: Project Boundary in digital format (.shp or .kmz)
Aquatic Resources Jurisdictional Delinea.AnL1:
• Access to the survey area will not be restricted.
  • Field work will occur during the growing season/when conditions are appropriate for delineation.
  • A draft of the report will be provided to the client and one round of revisions will be addressed.
  • Revisions are assumed to be minor and not require additional field work.
Aquatic Resources Jurisdictional Delinea.Del1:
• Aquatic Resources Delineation Report
  • AJD decision from the USACE

Section 8 Facility Specific Analysis.RC1: Section 8 of the Supplemental Final Environmental Impact Statement (SEIS) for the Clark County Regional Flood Control (CCRFCD) Master Plan specifies procedures to evaluate new CCRFCD facilities. These project-specific procedures include National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA)-based decision processes to assess the potential site-specific impacts associated with a particular facility.
Section 8 Facility Specific Analysis.Des1: A concise document summarizing environmental impacts will be prepared following the process detailed in the CCRFCD SEIS. The EA will follow the format accepted by CCRFCD on past similar projects and will describe the purpose and need for the project, describe the Proposed Action and alternatives, provide a project description, provide a discussion of the affected environment, describe environmental consequences of the Proposed Action, propose mitigation measures for identified impacts, as appropriate, and include names and addresses of neighboring property owners.
Section 8 Facility Specific Analysis.Methods1: UES will evaluate baseline conditions and determine site-specific environmental impacts using tiering from the SEIS. The initial evaluation will identify potential impacts as described in Chapter 8. Resources likely impacted by the proposed facility will be analyzed primarily through SEIS charts and maps, minimizing the need for extensive field surveys. Evaluated resources include Geology and Soils, Groundwater Hydrology, Visual Resources, Socioeconomics, Land Use, Air Quality, Noise, Environmental Justice, and Surface Water (assuming no US Army Corps permit required).
Section 8 Facility Specific Analysis.AnL1: • The fee assumes that all field services will be performed under safety Level D personal protective procedures and that up to two site visits will be made by UES personnel.
Section 8 Facility Specific Analysis.Del1:
• The report will provide a discussion of findings, conclusions, and recommendations regarding the current environmental condition of both the project site and surrounding area.
  • Written review comments on the Draft document provided by Client, the applicant, and CCRFCD will be addressed and incorporated in a final version.
  • An electronic copy of the analysis report will be provided.

Desert Tortoise Monitoring.RC1: The desert tortoise is a federally threatened species protected under the Endangered Species Act. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service requires biological monitoring during construction of the temporary tortoise exclusion fencing and ongoing monitoring of the fencing to minimize impacts to tortoises.
Desert Tortoise Monitoring.Des1: UES will provide qualified biologists to monitor project construction activities to maintain compliance with the Biological Opinion document for the project.
Desert Tortoise Monitoring.Methods1: Biological monitors will sweep ahead of project vehicles to guide them away from sensitive habitat and avoid impacts to tortoises, as well as provide a Worker Environmental Awareness Program (WEAP) training to onsite staff. If tortoise fence is in use for any part of the project, biologists may inspect the fence to ensure it in good repair, as well as monitor for pacing tortoises along the fenceline.
Desert Tortoise Monitoring.AnL1: • UES is not responsible for fence installation, only monitoring during construction and checking fences after installation.
Desert Tortoise Monitoring.Del1: • Biological monitors on site during temporary exclusion fence construction as well as fence checks, if applicable.

Cacti and Yucca Survey.RC1: The project alignments cross U.S. Bureau of Land Management (BLM) lands. The BLM has determined that an inventory of cacti and yucca within the project right-of-way is required to determine appropriate mitigation. Cacti and yucca in permanent impact areas may be sold to the public or mitigated via a fee. Plants in temporary disturbance areas will be salvaged and replanted on-site after construction.
Cacti and Yucca Survey.Des1: UES will conduct a comprehensive survey of the project boundary to inventory and map all cacti and yucca species present. The data will be analyzed to quantify the number of plants in the temporary and permanent disturbance areas to support BLM and SNWA in determining the required mitigation approach and fees.
Cacti and Yucca Survey.Methods1: A team of biologists will walk the entire project alignment and record data on each individual cactus and yucca encountered, including GPS location, species, height, health condition, and number of plants (for clustered species). The survey data will be processed in GIS and overlaid on the project design to calculate the quantity of plants within the temporary and permanent impact boundaries.
Cacti and Yucca Survey.CPI1:
• Project boundary in electronic format (shp. or kml)
  • Locations of temporary work areas.
Cacti and Yucca Survey.AnL1: • The survey will document cacti and yucca only, not other plant species. The survey will cover only the areas within the defined project boundaries and temporary work spaces provided by GCW.
Cacti and Yucca Survey.Del1: • Summary report of cacti/yucca survey findings, including quantities within impact areas, and GIS data files of all mapped cacti and yucca with associated metadata.

Bear Poppy Survey.RC1: The project area contains potential habitat for the bear poppy (Arctomecon californica), a BLM sensitive plant species. The BLM requires surveys of potential habitat during the appropriate blooming period to determine if the species is present and would be impacted by the project.
Bear Poppy Survey.Des1: A BLM-certified botanist from UES will conduct a targeted survey of the previously identified potential bear poppy habitat area during the spring blooming season. The survey will determine the presence or absence of the species within the defined habitat area.
Bear Poppy Survey.Methods1: The botanical survey will be scheduled during the appropriate identification period for bear poppy, typically early to mid-spring. The BLM-certified botanist will walk transects spaced to achieve 100% visual coverage of the potential habitat area. If any bear poppies are encountered, the locations will be recorded with GPS and the number of individuals documented. A brief technical memo will be prepared summarizing the survey methods and findings, including maps and any data collected on bear poppy occurrences.
Bear Poppy Survey.AnL1:
• The survey must be conducted during the spring blooming season.
  • The survey is limited to the potential bear poppy habitat area previously identified; it does not include a habitat assessment or surveys of the entire project footprint.
  • The survey is only for bear poppy; other sensitive plant species will not be recorded.
Bear Poppy Survey.Del1: • Technical memo documenting survey methods, results, and any bear poppy location data.

Bear Poppy Survey.RC4: The project area contains potential habitat for the bear poppy (Arctomecon californica), a BLM sensitive plant species. The BLM requires surveys of potential habitat during the appropriate blooming period to determine if the species is present and would be impacted by the project.
Bear Poppy Survey.Des4: A BLM-certified botanist from UES will conduct a targeted survey of the previously identified potential bear poppy habitat area during the spring blooming season. The survey will determine the presence or absence of the species within the defined habitat area.
Bear Poppy Survey.Methods4: The botanical survey will be scheduled during the appropriate identification period for bear poppy, typically early to mid-spring. The BLM-certified botanist will walk transects spaced to achieve 100% visual coverage of the potential habitat area. If any bear poppies are encountered, the locations will be recorded with GPS and the number of individuals documented. A brief technical memo will be prepared summarizing the survey methods and findings, including maps and any data collected on bear poppy occurrences.
Bear Poppy Survey.AnL4:
• The survey must be conducted during the spring blooming season.
  • The survey is limited to the potential bear poppy habitat area previously identified; it does not include a habitat assessment or surveys of the entire project footprint.
  • The survey is only for bear poppy; other sensitive plant species will not be recorded.
Bear Poppy Survey.Del4: • Technical memo documenting survey methods, results, and any bear poppy location data.

SWPPP Monitoring.Methods1: Qualified UES personnel will perform a routine site inspection once every seven calendar days and within 24 hours of the end of a storm event that is 0.5 inches of precipitation or greater for four (4) weeks. The inspections will cover all areas of the site where construction materials and activities are exposed to stormwater discharges. During each inspection, the integrity of the site BMPs will be evaluated and recommendations for general maintenance will be provided, as necessary. The SWPPP book will be maintained and updated as needed.

Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact.Task1: Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact Analysis
Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact.AcTask1: Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact Analysis
Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact.RC1: The US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) regulates the placement of dredged or fill material into all waters of the U.S. (WOTUS) under Section 404 of the Clean Water Act (CWA). Under Section 404 of the CWA, the USACE may issue a permit for the placement of fill material into WOTUS. The type of permit is dependent on the acreage of jurisdictional WOTUS present and impacted by a proposed project.
Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact.Methods1: Under this task, UES will conduct a site visit to the project area to document the presence and lateral extents of aquatic resources located within the project area. Data to be collected includes agency-provided datasheets, georeferenced photographs, and measurements of observable indicators of ordinary high water mark (OHWM).
Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact.CPI1:
• Project description information to include all work and elements that are proposed to occur in any stream channel located within the project boundary.
  • Project boundary and proposed design information in electronic format (ArcView/Info-compatible shape files) for project mapping.
  • Information regarding proposed access for construction and maintenance.
  • Location of temporary disturbance areas (workspace, lay down areas, spoils piles and borrow pits, etc.) and permanent disposal areas.
Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact.AnL1:
• Client will provide the right of entry to conduct the site visit during normal weekday business hours.
  • One draft of the aquatic resources delineation report and impacts analysis will be provided to the Client for review and comment prior to finalization. Comments are assumed to be editorial in nature and would not require additional fieldwork.
Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact.Del1:
• A draft and final Aquatic Resources Delineation Report will be provided.
  • A draft Impacts Analysis will be provided.
Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact.Task2: Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact Analysis
Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact.AcTask2: Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact Analysis
Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact.RC2: The US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) regulates the placement of dredged or fill material into all waters of the U.S. (WOTUS) under Section 404 of the Clean Water Act (CWA). Under Section 404 of the CWA, the USACE may issue a permit for the placement of fill material into WOTUS. The type of permit is dependent on the acreage of jurisdictional WOTUS present and impacted by a proposed project.
Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact.Methods2: Under this task, UES will use the field survey results to develop an aquatic resources delineation report that meets the USACE minimum standards including supportive mapping. UES will utilize this data and overlay the Client-provided project plans to calculate the proposed impacts to aquatic resources in order to determine the appropriate level of permitting under CWA Section 404.
Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact.AnL2: • A separate scope, schedule, and budget will be provided for the preparation of the application package to support the appropriate level of CWA Section 404 permit and the Nevada Division of Environmental Protection CWA Section 401 Water Quality Certification.
Aquatic Resources Delineation and Impact.Del2:
• A draft and final Aquatic Resources Delineation Report will be provided.
  • A draft Impacts Analysis will be provided.

USFWS Protocol Desert Tortoise Surveys.RC1: The Endangered Species Act (ESA) requires federal agencies to ensure that their actions do not jeopardize endangered or threatened species or their habitats. As the Mojave Desert Tortoise is an ESA listed species, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) requires consideration and mitigation for the tortoise when conducting projects within the species known range, including preconstruction surveys.
USFWS Protocol Desert Tortoise Surveys.Des1: The entire proposed project site will be evaluated for desert tortoise using the US Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) current survey protocols. The protocol outlines the survey methodology to determine presence/absence and abundance of desert tortoises.
USFWS Protocol Desert Tortoise Surveys.Methods1: Field surveys will be conducted according to USFWS requirements using parallel ten-meter (~30-ft) wide belt pedestrian transects. These will be surveyed by biological staff experienced with desert tortoise and sensitive biota of the Mojave Desert.
USFWS Protocol Desert Tortoise Surveys.AnL1:
• All areas of the project will be accessible.
  • Client comments will be editorial in nature and would not require additional field investigations or analyses.
USFWS Protocol Desert Tortoise Surveys.Del1:
• Results of the review of publicly available sources, including assessments of the jurisdictional limits for each federal and state agency. This includes relevant project mapping.
  • One round of client comments will be addressed.

Limited Lead Survey and Clearance.Des1: Per your request, UES proposes to conduct an initial lead survey and clearance for the subject property shown above. In addition to the limited lead survey, post abatement clearance testing will be performed at the completion of the removal of the lead from the project area. XRF analysis will be conducted on the discovered materials to verify lead content.
Limited Lead Survey and Clearance.Methods1: UES will conduct a desktop review of publicly available data sources and aerial imagery. UES will also conduct a site visit to document current field conditions of the project area identified by the Client. Field data to be collected includes georeferenced photographs, ordinary high water mark (OHWM) measurements, and general site descriptions.
Limited Lead Survey and Clearance.CPI1:
• Project boundary in electronic format (.kml or .shp)
  • Project description
  • Written notice to proceed
Limited Lead Survey and Clearance.AnL1:
• Client must provide the right of entry to conduct the survey during normal weekday business hours.
  • Samples will be collected in accessible areas from floor level, at existing ceiling access hatches or within reach of a standard 6-foot step ladder.
  • No areas containing suspect Lead and LBP will be obstructed or obscured by materials or equipment.
  • Any awareness of specialized knowledge or experience that is material to environmental conditions at the subject property shall be reported to UES by the Client prior to commencing the assessment work.
  • Lead and LBP surveys may not identify hidden or unsampled materials, especially those behind walls, above ceilings, or below flooring materials. As a general rule, no considered opinions can be issued regarding the qualitative or quantitative extent of suspect Lead and LBP without an appropriate scope of work which includes demolition of building components. Even then, it should be understood that there is no guarantee that all Lead and LBP in the building would be identified.
  • If additional samples beyond the number of clearance lead dust wipes outlined above are necessary, each will be invoiced for $40.00.
  • The fee is based on the assumption that only one site visit for sampling and one site visit for clearance will be made by field personnel. Should conditions be encountered which require additional services, we will contact you prior to initiating such work, explain the situation, and negotiate additional costs beyond those proposed herein.
Limited Lead Survey and Clearance.Del1:
• Verbal results of the initial survey will be provided onsite after receiving XRF analytical results.
  • Verbal results of the clearance survey will be provided within 24 hours of receiving analytical results (typically within 2 business days from sampling).
  • Final report detailing sampling activities, laboratory analysis, and general conclusions and recommendations (typically 10-15 days after sample collection).

Special Status Plant Survey.Methods1: A desktop survey of publicly available data sources will be reviewed to develop a target list of special status plant species (SSPS). BLM approved botanists will conduct the required field surveys. Prior to performing surveys, nearby SSPS reference locations will be visited to obtain a visual of the current phenological status of each species. Once the botanists are familiar with the targeted SSPS and their habitats, a project wide habitat assessment will be conducted. All data will be recorded using digital collection methods, including photographs, GPS coordinates, and plant list.

Asbestos Survey.Des1: The asbestos survey will be limited to accessible, interior areas located at the subject property. We propose to provide an asbestos survey of the project work area using an Asbestos Hazard Emergency Response Act (AHERA) accredited and State of Nevada licensed building inspector. The Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Code of Federal Regulations, 40 CFR Part 763 (AHERA), will be used as a guideline for the survey with respect to number of samples collected per homogeneous sampling area. The asbestos survey will also serve to assist the facility owner in the identification of ACMs at the subject site as required by the EPA’s National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants (NESHAP) in 40 CFR Part 61, and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) in 29 CFR Part 1926.1101.
Asbestos Survey.Methods1: The proposed asbestos survey would consist of sampling accessible, suspect friable and non-friable asbestos-containing materials (ACMs) found at the project work area. Bulk samples of suspect ACM; e.g. surfacing texture (acoustical or fireproofing), thermal system insulation, flooring materials, sheetrock wall systems, and other suspect miscellaneous material will be collected for laboratory analysis. We estimate that up to x______ bulk (or analytical layer) samples will be collected for the survey. The collected bulk samples will be analyzed by a qualified laboratory for asbestos using polarized light microscopy (PLM) methods. A final report will then be prepared which will detail the sampling activities, summarize the laboratory analysis in table format, and provide general conclusions and recommendations.
Asbestos Survey.CPI1:
• Any awareness of specialized knowledge or experience that is material to environmental conditions at the subject property shall be reported to UES by the Client prior to commencing the assessment work.
  • Project description
  • Written notice to proceed
Asbestos Survey.AnL1:
• Client must provide the right of entry to conduct the survey during normal weekday business hours.
  • Samples will be collected in accessible areas from floor level, at existing ceiling access hatches or within reach of a standard 6-foot step ladder
  • No areas containing suspect ACM will be obstructed or obscured by materials or equipment.
  • Asbestos surveys may not identify hidden or unsampled materials, especially those behind walls, above ceilings, or below flooring materials. As a general rule, no considered opinions can be issued regarding the qualitative or quantitative extent of suspect ACM materials without an appropriate scope of work which includes demolition of building components. Even then, it should be understood that there is no guarantee that all ACM in the building would be identified.
  • Some minor isolated damage to building materials during the sampling procedures may occur, but we will attempt to limit such damage to the nominal amount necessary for sample collection. UES will not be responsible for damage to or replacement of any sampled building materials.
  • If additional bulk or analytical layer samples beyond 135 are necessary, each will be invoiced for $35.00. The fee is based on the assumption that only one site visit will be made by field personnel. Should conditions be encountered which require additional services, we will contact you prior to initiating such work, explain the situation, and negotiate additional costs beyond those proposed herein.
  • If any of the sample results are less than 1%, each layer will be analyzed by point counting analysis for $65.00 (Standard Turnaround Time) with client approval. If any of the non-friable organically bound (NOB) material sample results are non-detect for asbestos, one sample per material will be reanalyzed by TEM Chatfield analysis for $120.00 (Standard Turnaround Time) with client approval.
Asbestos Survey.Del1:
• Verbal results will be provided within 24 hours of receiving all analytical results, which is typically 3-5 business days from sampling (or expedited for additional fee).
  • A final report will be provided to the Client (3-5 business days)
  • If requested, three printed copies will also be prepared and held for pick up at our office or sent via first class mail

We estimate that up to x______ bulk (or analytical layer) samples will be collected for the survey. The collected bulk samples will be analyzed by a qualified laboratory for asbestos using polarized light microscopy (PLM) methods. A final report will then be prepared which will detail the sampling activities, summarize the laboratory analysis in table format, and provide general conclusions and recommendations.
Asbestos Survey.CPI2:
• Any awareness of specialized knowledge or experience that is material to environmental conditions at the subject property shall be reported to UES by the Client prior to commencing the assessment work.
  • Project description
  • Written notice to proceed
Asbestos Survey.AnL2:
• Client must provide the right of entry to conduct the survey during normal weekday business hours.
  • Samples will be collected in accessible areas from floor level, at existing ceiling access hatches or within reach of a standard 6-foot step ladder
  • No areas containing suspect ACM will be obstructed or obscured by materials or equipment.
  • Asbestos surveys may not identify hidden or unsampled materials, especially those behind walls, above ceilings, or below flooring materials. As a general rule, no considered opinions can be issued regarding the qualitative or quantitative extent of suspect ACM materials without an appropriate scope of work which includes demolition of building components. Even then, it should be understood that there is no guarantee that all ACM in the building would be identified.
  • Some minor isolated damage to building materials during the sampling procedures may occur, but we will attempt to limit such damage to the nominal amount necessary for sample collection. UES will not be responsible for damage to or replacement of any sampled building materials.
  • If additional bulk or analytical layer samples beyond 135 are necessary, each will be invoiced for $35.00. The fee is based on the assumption that only one site visit will be made by field personnel. Should conditions be encountered which require additional services, we will contact you prior to initiating such work, explain the situation, and negotiate additional costs beyond those proposed herein.
  • If any of the sample results are less than 1%, each layer will be analyzed by point counting analysis for $65.00 (Standard Turnaround Time) with client approval. If any of the non-friable organically bound (NOB) material sample results are non-detect for asbestos, one sample per material will be reanalyzed by TEM Chatfield analysis for $120.00 (Standard Turnaround Time) with client approval.
Asbestos Survey.Del2:
• Verbal results will be provided within 24 hours of receiving all analytical results, which is typically 3-5 business days from sampling (or expedited for additional fee).
  • A final report will be provided to the Client (3-5 business days)
  • If requested, three printed copies will also be prepared and held for pick up at our office or sent via first class mail
Asbestos Survey.Des3: The asbestos survey will be limited to accessible, interior areas located at the subject property. We propose to provide an asbestos survey of the project work area using an Asbestos Hazard Emergency Response Act (AHERA) accredited and State of Nevada licensed building inspector. The Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Code of Federal Regulations, 40 CFR Part 763 (AHERA), will be used as a guideline for the survey with respect to number of samples collected per homogeneous sampling area. The asbestos survey will also serve to assist the facility owner in the identification of ACMs at the subject site as required by the EPA’s National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants (NESHAP) in 40 CFR Part 61, and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) in 29 CFR Part 1926.1101.

Fungal Investigation.Des1: UES will conduct a limited fungal investigation for the project areas in the subject property. The fungal investigation will be conducted at accessible interior areas, located at the subject property, specified by the client. UES will utilize a thermal imaging camera and moisture meter to assist the investigation.
Fungal Investigation.Methods1: The proposed initial fungal investigation would consist of a limited visual inspection, surface tape lift sampling (up to x___ samples from the areas of concern, directed by the client), and spore trap fungal ambient air sampling (up to x___ samples from the areas of concern, directed by the client), within the project area of the subject property. The collected samples will be analyzed by a qualified laboratory for fungal spores using microscopy method with Standard Turnaround Time (3 Business Days).

NDF Take Permit.Des1: After field surveys are complete, data will be processed and used for a NDF Take Permit. The permit package will follow NDF’s guidelines, including all required documentation, mapping, and data. The package will be submitted to the agency as soon as practicably possible.
